data.Audit Team: Junaid Rafey - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Ashar Mushtaq - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Shahid Karim - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: It was observed that permits: Are currently stored outside, not immediately accessible at the work-front or the CCR. Permits are not cross referenced to an isolation diagram. The risk is that: Workers are not able to easily refer to the permit during the task. CCR/ERT is not able to quickly understand impact of operational change or incident on active permits. Workers using a permit may not be clear on energy isolation in-place and will be unable to verify current isolation standard vs. requirement. For example, losses have occurred due to wrong flanges being broken. Permit management was a key factor in the Piper Alpha disaster (to this day, the largest PD loss in history). For complex isolations, there may be multiple work fronts which need to be closed prior to re-isolation. Cross referencing is essential for operations to confirm suitability to re-energize system.

data.Audit Team: Junaid Rafey - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Ashar Mushtaq - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Shahid Karim - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: It was observed that on the A-300 Furnace isolation plan, a spool removal was not captured on the isolation plan. In addition, the operations team had removed a spool, which was marked as a blind location on the isolation plan. The risk is that an error could be made when returning the isolated system back into operations, due to the isolation plan not reflecting the actual status of the system and the isolations in place. This risk increases with more complex isolation plans where the plan does not reflect the status in the field. This could lead to a LOPC event during re-energization of the system and a potential fire / explosion – ignition of a gas leak is very likely for furnace area LOPC.

data.Audit Team: Junaid Rafey - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Ashar Mushtaq - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Shahid Karim - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: It was observed that, the site permit audits did not highlight items identified in 23.02 and 23.03. Given that only a single permit was reviewed during the survey and gaps vs. best-in-class performance were found it suggests that the site auditing system should be routinely finding gaps and driving improvements. However, it was communicated that there were no permit audit findings of note in 2022. The risk is that the site does not organically improve the permit standards above the site current position. An effective auditing system should drive continuous improvement towards best-in-class performance.

data.Audit Team: Junaid Rafey - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Ashar Mushtaq - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Shahid Karim - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: It was observed that maintenance KPIs have improved since previous visit, but do not adequately show site management current risk position when compared to best-in-class performance. Survey team was unable to easily see number of overdue SCD PMs, CMs, on-hold items and open notifications which are not yet work orders. The risk is that site management cannot effectively be aware if the current risk level changes, or if today’s risk level is acceptable. This may lead to under resourcing of this critical department and subsequent losses occurring.

data.Audit Team: Junaid Rafey - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Ashar Mushtaq - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Shahid Karim - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: It was observed that there is currently a utility pump running, feeding into the firewater circuit for non-emergency use process water on site. Site shared that this was acceptable via current practices as the firewater pumps are not being used, despite excess capacity of the F/W main being used. The risk is that the additional hydraulic constraint on the system reduces the maximum attainable flow through the firewater system. In the event of a fire scenario, it is unlikely that process water use will be stopped as priority will be on emergency response. However, the maximum use case may not be possible, impacting firefighting effectiveness and exacerbating the loss.

data.Audit Title: RMA - 2023 Escape Mask Audit of PVC-1&2 Plant
data.Finding: Escape masks audit carried out at PVC-1/2 Field Offices, which were found in good condition. Masks were protected by plastic bags to prevent from dust and other environmental conditions. Cartridges expiry also checked, found OK except 02 mask whose cartridges were going to expire in July-2023, which will be replaced accordingly and other having expiry in year - 2025. Escape mask boxes may be sealed with yellow car seal to avoid unauthorize use by someone.

data.Audit Title: Non-Operating area building safety audit as per RMA (Admin Block, Admin building, Hussain Dawood building & Main canteen)
data.Responsible for Action Plan: Syed Ali Majid Shah - EPCL Plant
data.Responsible for Action Plan Review: Syed Ali Majid Shah - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: Below are the findings of N0n-operation area building safety audit. ADMIN BLOCK 1. Proper cable management & cable routing required inside transport office. 2. Push & Pull sign required on glass door & circle sign also need to be pasted. ADMIN BUILDING 1. Fire alarm system “MCP & detectors” missing inside HR & Planning room. 2. Valve placed under table inside office of planning section. 3. Emergency exit sing found missing on door. 4. Ceiling tile observed in loose condition which may lead to falling hazard. STORM WATER CHANNEL 1. Safety railing required at both sides of storm water channel for prevention of falling hazard. HUSSAIN DOWOOD BUILDING 1. Cover found missing on power connection point of geyser. 2. Very improper cable routing observed as cable is routed in walkway & inside plantation area. 3. Very improper cable routing observed as cable observed in loose condition. 4. Emergency exit sings found missing on exit doors at ground & 1st floor. MAIN CANTEEN 1. Fire alarm system “MCP & detector” missing inside kitchen. 2. Emergency exit door found locked & access not cleared due washing point. May cause tripping hazard. 3. Glass found in damaged condition of kitchen food delivery section which may cause hand injury.

data.Audit Title: Housekeeping Audit - EVCM Plant as per RMA
data.Finding: Below are the findings of Housekeeping audit. 1. Proper rack placement required for stacking of scattered hoses at west side of T-80 C 2. Housekeeping required to remove unnecessary stacked material in area at T-80B north side. 3. Housekeeping required to remove unnecessary stacked material in area at T-80B north side. 4. Housekeeping required to remove civil debris & other material near Bullets area. 5. Housekeeping required to remove civil debris & other material near Bullets area. 6. Housekeeping required to remove unnecessary stacked material from area near MF – 608 D. 7. Housekeeping required to remove unnecessary stacked material in area at MF – 608. 8. Housekeeping required to remove unnecessary stacked material in area at LTC west side. 9. Housekeeping required to remove unnecessary stacked material in area at MS – 202. 10. Trash bin found overflowed inside lube oil shed. 11. Housekeeping required to remove unnecessary stacked material near Lube oil shed EVCM. 12. Roof drain need to be routed towards channel as algae formation is causing slippery hazard - TR-EDC-03. 13. Un-necessary stacked light pole need to be removed from area at 300 area. 14. Drain channel cover need to be placed near MF – 805. 15. Fixing required of drain channel cover for prevention of any incident near PP-806 C. 16. Excessive stacking of civil debris observed in area which need to be removed at east side EVCM. 17. Civil debris removal required near MF 902 B tank.

data.Audit Title: JCC for UTY-3 Neut pit transfer to base plant
data.Finding: Pit transfer as per procedure however procedure has mentioned Neut pit LT low alarm is on 0.3 meter which is now change to 0.5 meter on DCS before pit cleaning in last outage, secondly neut pit transfer pump indications are not available on DCS due to PLC control and indication is only from Modbus its MOC for logic change i.e pump cut in cut off with pH analyzer is on hold since long mentioned in SIC log follow up.

data.Recommendation: It is frequently observed that color coding disappears during usage so regime to be established for reapplying color to ensure there are zero audit observations.
data.Finding: During machinery tools audit, one millwright tools were assessed including screw drivers, spanners and hammers. Although all tools were healthy and found in good condition, but their color coding (green) was disappeared so after health verification, color was reapplied. Other millwright tools were found in good condition as well with color coding intact.

data.Audit Team: Hassan Masroor - EPCL Plant; Mehboob Ahmed Khan - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Abdullah - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Adris - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Shoquaib Farooq - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Usama Bin Aijaz - EPCL Plant; Muzzamil Shahzad - EPCL Plant; Osama Jawaid - EPCL Plant; Sobia Shariq - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: During the exercise, 239 MAH threat cases were identified among which 172 were taken from Past PHAs (Consequence Level C4) and 67 were new potential MAH cases based on P&IDs review and operational experiences. After evaluation by the team, it was finalized that a total of 66 cases have the consequence with potential of single and multiple fatalities along with significant property asset and environmental damage and were therefore declared as MAH scenarios. Significant efforts were put in to evaluate existing controls to mitigate and reduce the risk of these cases. Along with existing controls, 40 new recommendations which include both engineering and administrative controls that are suggested to reduce the risk factor of the unit. However due to low reliability of some equipment such as C-1495, there exists at least 03 scenarios due to which the site is exposed to high operational risk. Mechanical integrity of FRP vessels, lines and metallic lines were questioned as frequent leakages were observed in the past. After detailed review of maintenance and inspection plans such as SEMI, it was concluded that currently, the system is reliable and constant replacements are being done to increase the overall reliability of vessels and piping network.

data.Finding: Fire Extinguisher was not present in Excavator. Open Rotary were observed in Vehicles. Trailer spark arrestor was missing. Tires condition of Loader`s were not good. Workers damage shoes were observed at site. In rest area Electric Fan was not installed for workers. Sitting area near salt yard is not fenced/secured from Earth vehicle movement. Area owners need to install hard barricading & restrict the Vehicle EVM in that area. Resp. CA OPS East side of the salt yard need to be fenced or hard barricaded to avoid unnecessary contact of EME & pedestrians. Resp. CA Ops Blind spot is created while you are approaching the salt yard due to scaffold structure at MCC construction site of HPO. Speed breakers need to be installed 2 meters before HPO MCC towards Salt yard road. Resp. HPO Construction Pedestrians use the temporary road/pathway to access the construction site of (HPO site) which is East side of the salt yard (The road is between salt yard & HPO MCC) & across the road toward south side near to approach HPO CT construction site. Therefore, the following should be followed

data.Audit Title: Escape Mask Audit of PVC-1&2 Plant RMA-2023
data.Audit Team: Dilawar Raheem - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Irfan Alahi - EPCL Plant; Usama Arshad - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: Escape masks audit carried out for PVC-1/2 Field Offices and below are the observations. 1- Mask were found in good condition. 2- Masks were protected by plastic bags to prevent from dust and other environmental conditions. 3- Cartridges expiry also checked, found OK except 02 mask whose cartridges were going to expire in July-2023, which will be replaced accordingly. It is suggested that Escape Mask Boxes may be sealed with yellow car seal to avoid unauthorize use by someone.

data.Audit Title: JCC Audit Conducted as Per RMA
data.Audit Team: Akbar Ali - EPCL Plant; Amir Iqbal - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: 1-JCC compliance was checked and found that I&E has the highest incompliance followed by E-VCM, PVC III and Maintenance as shown in the figure below. 2-In Operations, some high risks jobs are not covered in the JCC matrix like H2SO4 unloading activity. The procedures for this job are also not found. 3-Some high-risk jobs do not have procedures like Hoist operating guidelines. 4-Several jobs were discussed which are carried out after JSA, and are also relatively frequent, but were neither included in the list of JCC activities, nor punched in the system. 5-The maintenance team planned JCC audit of flange bolt cutting. It was observed that they haven’t SOP of flange bolt cutting. 6-It was noted that the JCC are not punched weekly in the system but are instead submitted at the end of the month.

data.Audit Type (EPCL): 135-Vehicles Audit - Tires, Glass Break, 3rd Party, Fire Extinguisher etc.
data.Finding: During rigging tools following were observations were noted 1- Crane driver cabinet exposed wiring 2- Crane tires damaged & worst condition 3- Scaffolding pipes were erected in mid of Electric chain hoist without any warning signage at PVC-I Hoist 4- Power cables pendant not properly secure of PVC-I Hoist 5-Overhead crane loose safety lock at main workshop 6-Dry and dusted wire drum valve shop jib crane 7-Jib crane operators list not pasted nearby 8-Two out of one hook latch not working properly of UTY-II Over head crane.

data.Audit Title: General Safety Audit OF EVCM Plant
data.Finding: During Audit Following Observations Were observed, 1:TT-306-B Water Sprinklers were closed by placing cooldrink bottles on its face as well as Sprinklers was not taken on defeat 2:Damage dyke at area-100 3:Scattered Insulation and without securing in bags EVCM lube shed 4:Damage or Rusted Drain channel at 200 area 5:Steam pipe nozzle was out of drain channel at area-800 6:Scaffolding material stacking In front of Fire hydrant area-100 7:Cracked/ damage foundation of PG Support at area 100 8:Poor Housekeeping at area - 200 9:Water leakage and spill at Several locations of EVCM Plant 10:Fire Extinguisher was placed on ground level instead of holding position at West of Old MCC 11: Mirror of Gauge at reboiler platform 12:AKS worker was doing painting job while standing H beam at 400 gallery

data.Finding: 1-Safety railing found damaged of pit, which is serious concern & may lead to fall hazard. 2-Very poor housekeeping observed in area due to wooden pallets, used cotton gloves, drain channel covers & other material found badly scattered. 3-Wooden box cover observed with raised nails. Removal required from area. 4-Housekeeping required to remove un-identified material stacked in bags & other material found scattered. 5-Housekeeping required to remove scrap material from safe assembly point card punch location. 6-Drain channel found filled / blocked with dry grass & trash. (Cleaning required) 7-Water found stagnant on floor causing hurdle for pedestrians, Wooden pallets placed for crossing. 8-Pieces of damaged corrugated sheets found scattered in area. 9-Service hose found scattered in front of safety shower. 10-Large wooden boxes & other material found stacked on road with any barrication or safety cones.

data.Audit Title: Car Seal Audit conducted as per RMA
data.Finding: 1. In Utilities, a few car seals were not locking the valve properly as shown in Fig 1. 2. Different colors of car seals were used. For CSO green color is used, and for CSC red color is used but white color car seals are also observed which is neither indicate CSO nor CSC as shown in Fig 2. 3. At Utilities, the Car seal of HV-2416A was missing as shown in Fig 3. 4. Few of the Car seal tags are not updated in the list e.g.: Car Seal no:19257787, 19257784 in utility plant. Car Seal no: 015669 in CA Plant. Car Seal of FT-1663A/B (Upstream valve) and Car Seal of LCV-1662 (Upstream valve towards SC-1680) 5. Status of a few Car Seal were not marked e.g.: C-1460 as shown in Fig.4 6. In the Checklist of CA, Some of the Car seals were written as not accessible. As shown in Fig.4 7. In one checklist of PVC III, the SIC sign was missing.

data.Recommendation: Overall system was working fine. However, LEL detectors calibration and sensor replacement frequency to be re-evaluated in coordination with OEM.
data.Finding: Carried out cleaning of 2 LEL sensors - Checked regarding Mounting stand support, found normal. - Cleaning done of its sensor guard. - Checked Zero reading and found ok. - Cable gland found ok. -1 Sensor was found weak and was replaced as it had some drift. - Check triggering of Detector on high LEL and verified complete loop of system Overall system was working fine. However, LEL detectors calibration and sensor replacement frequency to be re-evaluated.

data.Finding: VCM vapors were coming from PU-1104 suction strainer u/s valve during strainer cleaning. Administrative controls were in place. Clear instruction of full face mask usage mentioned on permit and properly were being used. Acton item: Further valve will be replacement to be planned with stationary. So that it can be replaced in NAO.

data.Audit Title: RMA - Safe Operating Limits Excursion Analysis of PVC-1/2 Plant
data.Audit Team: Muhammad Umair Khan - EPCL Plant; Waqas Ahmad - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: Safe operating limit excursion analysis carried out PVC-1&2 plants. Some SCD instruments high (high) pressure / temperature alarms sounded due to tight reaction profile due to rise in cooling water temperature as well valve tunning issues / weather condition. Please find attached file for detail reference.

data.Finding: Audit conducted of JCCs conducted from March till June 2023. Below are the observations: 1. Procedures availability found satisfactory 2. Out of 8 JCCs, 6 were conducted and 2 were not conducted because no job was planned in those months against the specific procedure due to job nature. For rectification of this observation, JCC plan needs to be aligned with PM plan and annual Turn Arounds window.

data.Recommendation: Complete Rehabilitation of area is required
data.Finding: • RCC Structure of CA 1600 area including columns & beam are moderately damaged. • Slabs & machine foundations are severely damaged. • Reinforcement of slab is exposed, corroded, and rusted at multiple locations. • Spalling of concrete, strength loss, major and minor cracking, disintegration, concrete efflorescence is visible in concrete members at multiple locations. • Steel stairs and railings are found corroded with loosened joints.

data.Audit Title: RMA - Heavies / EDC / Caustic / Hypo Tanker Mock Drills
data.Audit Type (EPCL): 54-Heavies / EDC / Caustic / Hypo Tanker Mock Drills
data.Audit Team: Ateeq Ahmed - EPCL KHI NM; Zafar Iqbal - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: Scenario: Valve leakage of HCL Tanker Positives: - PPEs well maintained - Proper Communication with supervisor - Stop sign and Road safety signed properly placed - De-contamination was properly done - Proper Dike Preparation Areas of Improvement: - Area not Barricaded accordingly. - MSDS knowledge was inadequate. - Driver was unaware of extent of leakage - Traffic Control needs improvement - Improper communication between driver and helper - PPE donning time exceeded the defined time limit i.e. 2 minutes

data.Audit Title: Plant Hose hydro testing & inspection (PVC, UTY, VCM, CA) ; D9
data.Audit Type (EPCL): 81-Plant Hose hydro testing & inspection (PVC, UTY, VCM, CA)
data.Template: Job Cycle Check (JCC) Evaluation Form [FORM # SAF-101/ Rev 0 (28/04/15)]
data.Audit Team: Ahtisham Qadir Malik - EPCL Plant; Amer Ahmed - EPCL Plant; Faheem Ahmed - EPCL Plant; Faisal Ahmed - EPCL Plant; Junaid Rafey - EPCL Plant; Zafar Ali - EPCL Plant
data.Checklist Category: Job Cycle Check (JCC) Evaluation Form [FORM # SAF-101/ Rev 0 (28/04/15)]
data.Question: Does the employee use proper PPE to perform the job?
data.Recommendation: Flushing of hoses after use of chemical transfer Avoid to shifting hoses from one unit to other Handling, Installation, and Storage Guidelines as per Equity Engineering Practice EP 5-4-4: Flexible Hoses Installation & Handling: 1. Hose should be handled with care. All hoses shall be installed per the manufacturer's installation recommendations for bend radius; bending beyond the minimum bend radius will reduce the hose life. 2. If the hose is kinked during installation, discard immediately. 3. Hose assemblies shall not be installed or operated in a twisted or torqued condition. Swivel fittings may be used in the layout design to aid in torque free installation. 4. Hoses are designed for single plane of flexibility only. Flex in multiple planes at the same time can reduce the service life of the hose and cause failures. 5. Verify hose has sufficient slack to allow for slight change in length on pressurizing or cooling. 6. Verify hose is not in direct contact with hot surfaces. 7. Hose should be run straight out of a fitting junction and should not be bent sharply into a junction. 8. For hoses in pressurized systems, the risk of hose whipping exists if the fittings become disconnected; consider the use of guards and restraints to mitigate the risks. 9. Avoid pulling hoses over or along sharp objects and scuffing over rough floors. 10. Where multiple hoses are connected, hoses should feature a safety cable to reduce whipping. 11. Where Cam Locks are supplied as the desired hose fitting, the arms shall be locked down by means of secondary securing. Storage: 1. Prior to storage, each hose shall be free of water, debris, metal shavings, dirt, or any other foreign material that may cause problems to the application. Air or nitrogen may be blown through the assembly to remove any loose particles. 2. All hoses shall be stored in such a manner to protect them from degrading factors such as humidity or moisture, temperature extremes, direct sunlight, corrosive liquids, or any other degrading atmosphere. 3. Hoses shall be stored hanging with open ends free to drain any excess water or debris. Do not hang hoses such that the maximum design bend radius is exceeded. 4. Care should be taken if hoses are stacked, as their weight can crush hoses at the bottom of the stack and stacks can become unstable, creating a safety hazard. 5. If stored below freezing, pre-warming may be required prior to handling, testing, and placing into service. Ideal temperature for hose storage is 50°F to 70°F (10°C to 20°C). 6. First-in/first-out stocking methods should always be used.
data.Response: Hose handling and management guidelines issued at site
data.Finding: Total 81 hoses inspected, 52 hoses accepted and 29 hoses rejected

data.Audit Title: Job Cycle Check of Drain Channel Cleaning Activtiy
data.Finding: At some locations in plant channels are covered with concrete blocks and heavy metallic sheets, during channel cleaning activity these locations are unable to clean as Blocks/heavy metallic sheets can't be removed, it's recommended these locations to be cover with normal channel covers for channels proper cleaning.

data.Audit Title: JCC-2023 VCM Sampling from TK-3B/8B at PVC-2 Plant
data.Audit Team: Haroon Anwar - EPCL Plant; Sheheryar Wazir - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: TK-8B VCM sampling activity monitored, which was well executed by Lab person Haroon and AE Shaheryar Wazir. Sampling procedure got expire last month, however following to be added in newly formatted procedure. 1- Information passing to DCS Engineer to be added during TK-8B/3B dyke entry. 2- Hose connection to N2 sample point to be added, related precautions, tested / tagged hose to be used. 3- Leak test of hose and sampling boom assembly to be done during purging activity.

data.Audit Title: JCC: Procedure for PU1104 suction strainer cleaning
data.Finding: JCC performed to check PU-1104 suction strainer cleaning activity against developed procedure. Revalidation of available procedure is due and must be done asap. Secondly, PU-1104 suction strainer u/s manual Ball valve has minor passing and causes exposure during cleaning activity. This valve has been sent for repair/ passing rectification twice during the current year 2023 but issue is NOT resolved yet. In the event of current issue of valve passing and its impact on personnel, it is strongly recommended to REPLACE valve at earliest.

data.Audit Type (EPCL): 52-Safety Shower and Eye Wash Flow Test
data.Finding: A total of 77 Safety and eye showers were audited in all operating areas such as Utilities/Power Plant, PVC – I, PVC – II, PVC – III, CA & EVCM. Flowrates and other observations were recorded as shown in the tables and explained in findings. Statistics are summarized as follows: 1) Overall, 69% of the safety shower & eye wash stations were found with adequate flow. 2) 23% of the safety shower & eye wash stations were found with observations related to operation or availability of accessories 3) Overall, safety shower & eye wash stations of Chlor Alkali & EVCM were found in good condition in comparison to other process units. 4) Most of the safety shower & eye wash stations of PVC – II, PVC – I, PVC - III & UTY/CCPP were observed with inadequate flows. 5) 62% of the 24 safety showers & eye wash stations with inadequate flow had low flow issue from eye wash nozzle only! For more information related to findings refer to attached report.

data.Audit Title: RMA - Heavies / EDC / Caustic / Hypo Tanker Mock Drills
data.Audit Type (EPCL): 54-Heavies / EDC / Caustic / Hypo Tanker Mock Drills
data.Audit Team: Ateeq Ahmed - EPCL KHI NM; Zafar Iqbal - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: Scenario: Bottom flange leakage of Caustic liquid soda Positives: 1. The communication was efficiently relayed to the transporter. 2. Traffic management was executed with a high level of proficiency. 3. The donning of personal protective equipment (PPE) was completed within the allocated two-minute timeframe. 4. Both drivers demonstrated a clear and mutual understanding of their responsibilities. 5. Cautionary signage was strategically positioned in accordance with safety protocols. 6. MSDs knowledge was very satisfactory. Areas of Improvement: People positioned against the direction of the wind were unaware of the potential harm caused by the caustic liquid and remained oblivious to the leakage.

data.Question: Audit Type
data.Help Text: Just add audit type here and attach soft copy of audit / checklist as attachment. Finding /Recommendations must be added in GENERAL RESULTS
data.Recommendation: Every box should have 5 masks on hand in case of an emergency.
data.Finding: Three of the seven boxes lacked an insufficient quantity of face masks, and Escape mask box 4 was totally empty, while boxes 2 and 5 only had one mask available.

data.Audit Title: IMS External Audit Reports 2023 findings (ISO-9001-2015 Quality Management Systems)
data.Audit Team: Muhammad Ali Shah - EPCL Plant; Somia Tariq - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: 1- Production - PVC - Finished Product PVC was spread on the floor where it was being filled into bags. Observation Class: Potential Non-Compliance Target Date: 30/12/2023 2- Production - UTY - A steam line (bypass) was damaged on the CT2 east side. Observation Class: Potential Non-Compliance Target Date: 30/05/2024 3- Production - CA - Rusted lines and tanks were found at several locations throughout the plant. Observation Class: Potential Non-Compliance Target Date: 30/05/2024 4- Production - CA - Insulation was damaged in the salt washing area where sand impurities get separated. Observation Class: Potential Non-Compliance Target Date: 30/04/2024 5- Technical - LAB - Following chemicals found expired in chemical room of QC lab. - Chemical- HNB - Expiry Feb 2023 - Chemical- Metal 100 PPM solution – Expiry Sept 2022. Observation Class: Potential Non-Compliance Target Date: 30/11/2023 6- Technical - LAB - Calibration status was not displayed or identified on the pressure gauges of compression molding machine in the QC lab. Observation Class: Potential Non-Compliance Target Date: 30/11/2023 7- HSE - Plant Clinic - Calibration status was not displayed or identified on the pressure gauges of the oxygen cylinder in clinic. Observation Class: Potential Non-Compliance Target Date: 30/11/2023 8- HSE - Safety - HSE Management review meeting was convened on 31st August 2023; minutes mostly covered the HSE topics; input and output topics relevant to QMS were reviewed during the meeting which are required to be documented in the minutes (Reference clause 9.3 of standards. Observation Class: Opportunity for Improvement Target Date: 30/04/2024 9- Maintenance - Stationary - Some of the tasks are completed physically but not closed in SAP system. This needs to be looked into for timely closure of actions as required. Observation Class: Opportunity for Improvement Target Date: 30/04/2024

data.Audit Title: IMS External Audit Reports 2023 findings (ISO-14001-2015) Environmental Management Systems)
data.Audit Team: Muhammad Ali Shah - EPCL Plant; Somia Tariq - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: 1- Production - PVC - Waste Tallerit Rings kept in an undesignated area without proper identification at PVC-1 Plant. Observation Class: Opportunity for Improvement Target Date: 30/11/2023 2- Production - PVC - Sulfuric acid was kept without secondary containment and no MSDS at PVC 1 plant were available Observation Class: Potential Non-Compliance Target Date: 30/04/2024 3- Production - CA - Used gloves were found on the floor at several locations of the plant. Observation Class: Opportunity for Improvement Target Date: 30/10/2023 4- Asset Integrity - Project - Mixed, unsegregated, unidentified waste was observed at the bins of project fabrication shop. Observation Class: Potential Non-Compliance Target Date: 30/12/2023 5- HSE - Environment - Environmental Monitoring NOISE: List needs to be improved with standard limits, number of people exposed and their TWA. Internal / External Monitoring: Action limits to be defined for each type of parameter being monitored (internal / external). Observation Class: Potential Non-Compliance Target Date: 30/04/2024

data.Audit Title: IMS External Audit Reports 2023 findings (ISO-9001-2015 Quality Management Systems) Non-Manufacturing
data.Audit Team: Muhammad Ali Shah - EPCL Plant; Somia Tariq - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: 1 - Lahore Sales offices- Marketing SITE-2 (HEAD OFFICE) SALES: A complaint was received on 19-07-2023; Case# 00001107, but as of now, no action has been taken to resolve it. According to procedure "Technical Services Manual (TSM-1)," the complaint resolution time is 30 days. Observation Class: Potential Non-Compliance Target Date: 30/11/2023 2 - Lahore Sales offices- Marketing HR: Centralized purchase and HR system needs to be addressed in respective procedures. Training effectiveness – methodology & frequency needs to be elaborated in the HR Procedure. Or during mid-year review by respective HOD / Supervisor. Observation Class: Potential Non-Compliance Target Date: 30/04/2024 3 - Lahore Sales offices- Marketing SITE-3 (LAHORE WAREHOUSE) a- Pictorial display of PPEs requirement in Sweep Waste drying/handling area required (Safety Issue). b- Vehicle Inspection before loading: Checks related to electrical system e.g. Positive functioning of headlights, horn, brake lights and all Indicators may be added in the checklist. c-Refresher training of staff for “Kinetic Lifting” at periodic basis to be conducted. Observation Class: Opportunity for Improvement Target Date: 31/12/2023

data.Audit Title: JCC | Chemical Preparation Activity at PVC-1&2 Plant
data.Finding: At PVC-2 plant DT-1 chemical preparation activity monitored and found OK. All step's execution carried out in an organized manner with upfront preparation / arrangements. USLs and area engineer were observed with proper PPEs. Communication between DCS Engineer and Day Assistant Engineer observed up to mark for managing chemical preparations on time. While at PVC-1 plant, only AG-6 chemical tank level make up was required. Area Engineer obtained required permit to connect flexible chemical hose with pneumatic pump and chemical shifting in area followed by AG-6 decanted into storage vessel. Check lists are attached for detail.

data.Audit Title: Drain Channel Audit Conducted of EVCM Unit
data.Finding: 1-Gaps and Chemical Contamination at drain channel of Area 400 Gallery. 2-Drain channel cover was found missing at 800 area. 3-Improper placement of drain channel cover at 800 area which increases the risk of slip/trip hazard. 4-Gaps were found at drain channel cover. Moreover, erected scaffolding was found on drain channel which increases the risk associated with unsafe practices. 5-Erected scaffolding was found on Drain Channel at area 100. 6-Damage and Sharp Edges were exposed of Drain Channel. 7-Misalignment of Drain channel cover that may cause Tripping hazard. 8-Improper and Misalignment of Drain channel covers were found and there were gaps between channels at Mainway of AVE-C near OVR. 9-At Street-12 Drain channels were damage and found without barricaded 10-Chemical contamination and Gaps at 700 area Mainway AVE-G

data.Audit Title: DRAIN CHANNELS & HOUSEKEEPING AUDIT OF CA PLANT
data.Finding: During drain channels & Housekeeping audit following observations were noted. 1-Drain channel covers were found missing, damaged, uneven and gaps observed at west of V-1020. 2-Brine sludge was found near drain channel covers which increases slip/trip risk. 3-Drain channel covers were found missing, damaged and unevenly placed west of Electrolyzer and V-1020. Scaffolding bracing was rested on drain channel cover. 4-Drain channel covers were found missing and improper small piece of cover was observed at south-west of Electrolyzer room. 5-Damage checker plate was placed at drain channel. 6-Gap was observed between drain channel covers. 7-Uneven and damaged drain channel covers were observed at east-north of 1000 area. 8-Uneven and missing drain channel covers were found in brine building.

data.Audit Team: Mubashir Hussain - EPCL Plant; Usama Arshad - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: PVC-1 SIP upkeep audit carried which was found OK. All gadgets found in good condition. Weekly monitoring check list is also being filled by team. However following issues were found, 1- 04 Elsa Packs out of 10 found with damaged face mask rubber and low pressure. 2- South side door having closing / sealing issue. 3- Air condition system need to be installed. 4- Sani Plast Bandage found expired placed in first aid box, which was replaced with having extended expiry by clinic. 5- Notifications were raised in SAP for rectification of SIP related issues. SIP card scanner (Head counting system) functioning also checked, which was found OK.

data.Audit Title: RMA: PVC-1 VCM sphere sprinkle testing
data.Finding: During operation of XSV8310, a significant quantity of water accumulates inside dyke. Although drain water pit exists there to collect water but due to elevation issue, water doesn't flow towards drain channel and remain stagnant there. Evaluation to be done by appropriate team to study and resolve water draining issue from dyke of VE-1106, as in case of long time operation (even 5 to 10 minutes) of sprinkle system, significant amount of water will accumulate there and would pose reliability issue for sphere structure in addition to movement issues.

data.Audit Title: Utility Points Audit EVCM & CA Plant
data.Audit Type (EPCL): 82-Piping, Piping supports and Equipment Conditions related audits
data.Finding: Following observations were noted. 1-Rusted flanges, missing handles and hose fixed with the help of binding wire posing sharp edge at EVCM Plant 400 & 600 area. 2-Missing cladding on the steam line and hose connection with the help of binding wire at EVCM Plant at 200 area. 3-Rusted, Corroded flanges of utility points and sharp-edged binding wires on the valve handle at EVCM Plant 200 area. 4-No identification tag marking of the utility points & Corroded flanges with stuck handles neither the lines were color coded as per chart at EVCM Plant 600area 5-Corroded rusted utility points without color coding & tagging at CA Plant 1000 area 6-Corroded, rusted utility points, damaged insulation cladding and chain was observed stuck on the valve at CA Plant 1200 area

data.Audit Team: A.Ali - EPCL Plant; Fahad Qureshi - EPCL Plant; Hafsa Rahmeen - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Abdullah - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Ashraf - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Safwan Khan - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Saim Khan - EPCL Plant; Salman Hadi - EPCL Plant; Zahid Hussain - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: During the exercise, more than 270 cases from PVC-II PHA were reviewed for potential MAH consequence. After evaluation by the team, it was finalized that a total of 53 cases have the consequence with potential of single and multiple fatalities along with significant property asset and environmental damage and were therefore declared as MAH scenarios. Significant efforts were put in to evaluate existing controls to mitigate and reduce the risk of these cases. Along with existing controls, 35 new recommendations which include both engineering and administrative controls that are suggested to reduce the risk factor of the unit. During the review, it was found out that approximately 15 hazards didn’t have adequate safeguards. To prevent these hazards turning into real MAH and to improve the reliability and quality of some existing safeguards, a total of 38 recommendations have been generated and approved by Sub HSE (P) forum.

text_content: Sheet: Audit Findings | Audit Number: AU-20231009-013 | Audit Location: Process Safety | Audit Title: PVC II Plant RBA Exercise | Auditor: Mujadid Ul Hassan - EPCL Plant | Start Date: 2023-10-09 00:00:00 | Audit Status: Closed | Audit Category: Audit | Auditing Body: 1st Party | Group Company: EPCL | Location (Epcl): PVC-II Back End | Audit Type (Epcl): 4-RBA | Template: General Audit Check List | Template Version: Current Version | Created By: Muhammad Abdullah - EPCL Plant | Audit Team: A.Ali - EPCL Plant; Fahad Qureshi - EPCL Plant; Hafsa Rahmeen - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Abdullah - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Ashraf - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Safwan Khan - EPCL Plant; Muhammad Saim Khan - EPCL Plant; Salman Hadi - EPCL Plant; Zahid Hussain - EPCL Plant | Responsible For Action Plan: Muhammad Abdullah - EPCL Plant | Responsible For Action Plan Review: Muhammad Shahid Karim - EPCL Plant | Entered Scheduled: 2023-12-12 00:00:00 | Entered In Progress: 2023-12-12 00:00:00 | Entered Review: 2023-12-12 00:00:00 | Entered Pending Action Plan: 2024-01-07 00:00:00 | Entered Review Action Plan: 2024-01-07 00:00:00 | Entered Pending Closure: 2024-01-07 00:00:00 | Entered Closed: 2024-01-14 00:00:00 | Finding: During the exercise, more than 270 cases from PVC-II PHA were reviewed for potential MAH consequence. After evaluation by the team, it was finalized that a total of 53 cases have the consequence with potential of single and multiple fatalities along with significant property asset and environmental damage and were therefore declared as MAH scenarios. Significant efforts were put in to evaluate existing controls to mitigate and reduce the risk of these cases. Along with existing controls, 35 new recommendations which include both engineering and administrative controls that are suggested to reduce the risk factor of the unit. data.Finding: Around 20 workers were observed working with mandatory PPEs. Two observations were rectified on the spot: 1. One worker was not wearing safety glass while watering the ground. data.Help Text: Just add audit type here and attach soft copy of audit / checklist as attachment. Finding /Recommendations must be added in GENERAL RESULTS
data.Recommendation: It was discussed with PM&S supervisor and officers to report such falling events as nearmiss to prevent recurrence.
data.Finding: We observed a top tier (3-tier) pallet fallen down and workers were collecting bags. The area was not barricaded and the bags fell down on the lifter pathway as well. When the matter was discussed with PM&S supervisor, I observed lack of understanding on reporting this event as nearmiss. However, PM&S supervisor and PM&S officers then agreed that it could resulted in an injury and it should be reported as nearmiss. The evident reason for falling of pallet was inappropriate pelleting of the entire row of bags (around 1000 bags in 3-tiers).
data.Action Item Description: The evident reason for falling of pallet was inappropriate pelleting of the entire row of bags (around 1000 bags in 3-tiers). They were tilting as well. It was discussed with PM&S team (Hammad & Aftab) to correct the situation to prevent any other bag falling event.
data.Action Item Responsible: Muhammad Zohaib Sufyan - EPCL KHI NM
data.Action Item Verification Details: yes as the point was rectified

data.Finding: 1- Overall housekeeping was good in I&E offices and workshop. 2- Paint condition was ok, touchup required at few locations. 3- locations were designated for material and properly marked. 4- Material was properly placed on designated locations. 5- Fire extinguishers placed at location & no inspection due on check list. 6- Water spilled beside water dispenser in workshop area may cause slip hazard. data.Audit Title: Fire Water Pumps Performance Test - November 2023
data.Question: Audit Type
data.Help Text: Just add audit type here and attach soft copy of audit / checklist as attachment. Finding /Recommendations must be added in GENERAL RESULTS
data.Finding: • Differential Head of Motor FW Pump (PU-8302A) was adequate (113 mH20 against 107 mH20) as per NFPA 25 requirement. • Diesel Engine Driven Pump meets the requirement of NFPA 25. • Differential Head developed by Diesel Engine FW Pump (PU-8302B) was adequate (119.45 mH20 against 104.5 mH20) as per NFPA requirement. • Motor Driven Pump meets the requirement of NFPA 25. • Slight Increment observed in Differential Head against previous Performance test.

data.Finding: Escape mask box should have 06 masks available on location. Only 05 masks were available. On discussion with the team, it was found that people who did not have masks available with them, were using masks from the box. This was discussed with the team in D-Level. It was communicated to the team that these masks can only be used in case of emergency.

data.Audit Title: PM&S I & II general safety audit
data.Finding: Following observations are noted during the audit. 1-The operator of the forty-mesh machine had improper hand placement, as he placed his hand on the vibrating. machine, posing the potential risk of a pinch. 2-The damaged Insulation of the Air blower, which was being used for forty mesh operation, was energized, and left unattended. 3-Obstacles were noted in front of the Energized Electrical DB, in the event of a fire emergency, reaching the location would be challenging. 4-The cooling fan on the forklift charger was observed to be faulty and not working. End caps were missing on the Electrical DB. Utility points were covered with cloth; however, end. caps should be installed instead. 5-The PVC bag was damaged, and a cotton glove was inserted to control the substance from coming out. 6-Damaged conveyer belts

data.Audit Title: General Safety Audit of EVCM Plant.
data.Finding: Following Observations are noted. 1-Rusted and Damaged permanent platform of MS-902 B east side. 2-Waste insulation & Sharpe edges cladding sheets pieces were placed on the cable tray of 400 gallery top Piperack. 3-On every platform of AS-301 B, placement of the sharp-edged loose material. 4-Waste 4” line left unattended on the cable tray of 400 gallery top south side. 5-400 gallery blocked due to unnecessary scaffolding erections. 6-Unnecessary insulation and cladding material at AS-801 scaffolding with missing toe board. 7-Gap in the pump guard and the rotary part is visible at PP-951. 8-Piece of sharp-edged cladding sheet in hanging condition at PP-403 B Piperack. 9-Unnecessary piping placement on the scaffolding platform at west side of 400 gallery. 10-

data.Audit Title: JCC | 2023 3 PU-9C/10C Suction Strainer Cleaning Activity
data.Finding: Shortstop pump's suction strainer cleaning activity monitored, execution found OK, however following deficiencies were observed, 1- ICC Filling, Defeat Protocol requirement not found in procedure, further to be updated due to its expiry. 2- Strainer to be drained / depressurized via suction line drain point instead of strainer top bolt. 3- Separate isolation valves at both pump's discharge to be installed for individual pump hand over.

data.Audit Title: RMA | Safe Operating Limit Excursion Analysis | PVC 1/2
data.Audit Team: Muhammad Anas - EPCL Plant; Waqas Ahmad - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: Safe operating limit excursion analysis carried out at both plants. Some SCD instruments high (high) pressure / temperature alarms sounded due to tight reaction profile owing to deviating cooling water temperature. Others involved FB issues of VSPs, premature RD rupture at PVC-2, motor tripping, GCs/startup shutdown etc, details are enclosed.

data.Audit Title: RMA - Heavies / EDC / Caustic / Hypo Tanker Mock Drills
data.Audit Type (EPCL): 54-Heavies / EDC / Caustic / Hypo Tanker Mock Drills
data.Audit Team: Aftab Ahmed - EPCL Plant; Zafar Iqbal - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: Scenario: Bottom flange leakage of Hydrochloric Acid Positives: 1. The communication was efficiently relayed to the transporter. 2. Traffic management was executed with a high level of proficiency. 3. The donning of personal protective equipment (PPE) was completed within the allocated two-minute timeframe. 4. Both drivers demonstrated a clear and mutual understanding of their responsibilities. 5. Cautionary signage was strategically positioned in accordance with safety protocols. 6. MSDs knowledge was very satisfactory. Areas of Improvement: People positioned against the direction of the wind were unaware of the potential harm caused by the hydrochloric acid and remained oblivious to the leakage. Driver doesn't know much about COSHH symbols

data.Audit Title: Salt yard to be reviewed for any HSE hazards
data.Finding: Findings 1 Payloader driver license not available. (Discussed with driver and as per him license is at home, asked him to carry the license during duty hours) Responsible - Ops/P&C 2 Oil Seepage observed from Pay loader (CAT 950 - B) Engine body which need to be rectify. Responsible - Ops/P&C 3 Covers missing on battery terminals which need to be covered / secured. (Battery termination covered to be installed in day shift, however battery is placed in CS box) Responsible - Ops/P&C 4 Loose wooden ply was placed on operator cabin outside Infront if stairs which may cause falling hazard. (Wooden piece has been removed) Responsible - Ops 5 Light found out of order at outside sitting area container. (Informed to electrical for rectification) Responsible - Electrical 6 Fire extinguisher seal found missing. (seal will be installed in day shift after taking from FC, however extinguisher pin is available) Responsible - Ops/HSE 7 Sitting container door cladding sheets need tobe secured to prevent form sharp edges. (To be rectified in day shift) Responsible - Stationary 8 Old Electrical DB on boundary wall need to be check as Bracker & open wires observed there. (Informed to electrical for rectification) Responsible - Electrical

data.Audit Title: RMA - Heavies / EDC / Caustic / Hypo Tanker Mock Drills
data.Audit Type (EPCL): 54-Heavies / EDC / Caustic / Hypo Tanker Mock Drills
data.Audit Team: Ateeq Ahmed - EPCL KHI NM; Zafar Iqbal - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: Scenario: Leakage from middle of bowsers Positives: 1. The communication was efficiently relayed to the transporter. 2. The donning of personal protective equipment (PPE) was completed within the allocated two-minute timeframe. 3. Both drivers demonstrated a clear and mutual understanding of their responsibilities. 4. MSDs knowledge was very satisfactory. 5. Driver's knowledge for product related was very good. 6. Good PPEs maintain, and all the necessary equipment's were rightly placed. 7. People positioned against the direction of the wind were aware of the potential harm caused by the caustic liquid and remained oblivious to the leakage. (which was the last weak point) 8. Wind direction was properly checked and Areas of Improvement: 1. Both drivers didn't come out of same locations. 2. Traffic hand signs weren't used as per standards. 3. Took a bit time for PPEs donning.

data.Audit Type (EPCL): 54-Heavies / EDC / Caustic / Hypo Tanker Mock Drills
data.Audit Team: Ateeq Ahmed - EPCL KHI NM; Zafar Iqbal - EPCL Plant
data.Finding: Company: Shakoor & Company Product: Caustic Vehicle: TLK-842 1st Driver name: Ghafoor Ali 2nd Driver name: Mohammad Asghar Scenario: 1-inch Dia hole at Bowser of vehicle Positives: - Very Well understanding between Drivers. - All elements are discussed with emergency team by drivers - very well understanding of MSDs of material - PPEs donning was done well before the time provided in procedure Areas of improvement: - one driver has worn glove above chemical suit but gives a valid explanation. - Barricading could be improve as very heavy wind was flowing. Overall Result: Satisfactory
